title: Thursday, 21st December, 2017
bodyHTML:

InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 4,668, up 62 (+1.35%), High: 4,675, Low: 4,578, Volume: 286.55k

Boncoeur @PM: ~20% corporation ta is the new consensus, causes problems for Corbyn given his desire to increase to 28% to fund tuition fees abolition.

Tax cut by a mid-to-high single digit percentage will add 11-12 per cent to EPS.

Bluesky21 IHG is 60% business travel ...

Bluesky21 ... it will do well just by corporates loosening purse strings on executives alone
11:08 am

Here comes Stifel with the detail.

BE11:08am

Assuming an 8 point tax reduction, the tax rate would decline to 23% in 2018, compared to current estimates of 31%, which would provide accretion to EPS of 11-12%. This is a more positive outcome compared to previous estimates of a 0-5 point reduction in the tax rate. We revise our earnings forecasts accordingly for 2018 and future years. Our new 2018 forecast is now 287.4c, some 11.7% higher than our previous estimates.

PM11:08am

I hadn't realised this -- that various companies will have to put out profit warnings to the upside

Boncoeur @fatdaz: yeah, I like flat taxes as well.

Punter Any grey on the proposed zero ground rent rule's impact on MCS which has dropped 9% on the news?

IHG’s cash tax payment in 2016 was 21% and it is expected that the cash tax charge will also decline as a result of the changes, although this will vary from year to year and no specific guidance is given. Our cash flow projections indicate that leverage will decline to 1.6x by the end of 2018, compared to the leverage target of 2.0-2.5x. Accordingly, in the absence of acquisition activity, it appears likely that there will be a further return of capital to shareholders in the next 12 months. Our projections indicate that the return of $500m would be accretive to EPS by around 3% on a pro forma basis.

BE11:12am

Other companies under our coverage with significant US exposure include Compass (Buy) with c62% NAM EBIT and Sodexo (Buy) with c40% NAM EBIT. Compass has previously suggested it would see little effect from US tax cuts, as its effective US tax rate is already low, the group rate is likely to be c26% in FY18E.
However, Sodexo's group tax rate at 32% (FY18E), suggests scope for a reduction in the tax rate of low-mid single digit percentage points and therefore mid-single digit consensus EPS upgrades. Given the complexity of these issues we will need to wait for clarification from the companies before updating our forecasts. IHG and Sodexo have performed strongly in recent weeks suggesting that these benefits are largely reflected in current share prices.

wayneJ Is all this leasehold stuff the ultimate 'financialisation' of simple transactions. In some way also relates to the discussion above re hotels. Between the capital provider (eg a property owner or a retired couple) and their return or benefit are layers of financial engineering.
BE11:21am

Let me cut to Cazenove to explain why it barely matters, like every other intervention in the housing market.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

It was widely expected that selling houses on
a leasehold basis would be banned, but the system around apartments was expected to be essentially unchanged. While it appears that selling freehold flats will be allowed, reducing the ground rents to zero means these would no longer have a value to be sold on. This has been a small, but relatively consistent profit stream for the housebuilders, particularly in recent years. We believe that currently the sale of packaged up ground rents accounts for c. 3% of profits at BKG (on current peak margin) and 1-3% at other housebuilders (although that estimate in many cases also includes the sale of freehold houses, which should have already been removed from profit expectations for next year). In our view, housebuilders are likely to attempt to reflect the lower cost to the home owner in higher selling prices (although this might be difficult in a falling London market) and adjust any remaining impact on profits through lower land values (at least on a long-term basis).

GBKrona @BE - banning leaseholds for just houses rather than flats, is that right?
Forester McCarthy say they have a strong case for an exemption.....struggling to see why!
wayneJ Weren't there two brothers who at one time were prominent in London who specialised in buying eg ex military accomodation and splitting the properties into ground rent and leasehold? What happened to them?
BE11:23am

@GBK, yes. Looks like flats can still be sold on a leasehold basis, but those leaseholds will no longer be subject to ground rents.

urgeview tchenguiz...still around

FATDAZ next area to crackdown on outrageous service charges with little or no service provision
FATDAZ @GBK great minds
Boncoeur Ground rent zero?!, great news, but since when. from when? Was this in the Autumn Budget 2017?

Bluesky21 @Fatdaz I think we are at risk of attacking the symptoms rather than the disease

To date, companies disclosure has been focused
on leasehold houses, most haven’t commented on profits from all ground rents. Logically companies with higher exposure to London should be more impacted, given that London accounts for a large proportion of apartments built by the sector.

GBKrona @WayneJ - no controls, just depends on the contract (lease) which generally are quite flaky
FATDAZ @Bluesky all for paying to have building maintained etc but too many seem to get away with doing v little abou that
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Only Berkeley discloses the sale of ground rents separately every year. In 2017 it accounted for 4% of profits. However, this is at current peak margin, if margins normalise, it would be closer to 5%. For Bellway, we know that the sale of ground rents accounted for £24m of profit (4% of op. profit), however this was a high year and group has guided that ground rent sales are expected to be materially lower this year (in part because of lower London volumes in FY17). We assume the exposure is slightly less at Countryside, Crest, Barratt, Taylor Wimpey and Redrow. Our assumption is that
Persimmon and Bovis have the lowest exposure, on the basis that they have no sales in London, and therefore fewer apartments in the mix.

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 4,141, down 69 (-1.64%), High: 4,200, Low: 4,137, Volume: 230.24k
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 204.50, down 1.5 (-0.73%), High: 205.10, Low: 202.70, Volume: 2.56m

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Jefferies to talk us through the stalled market.

BE11:28am

Housing transactions were flat in November and continue to increase (+7%) vs 2016. Overall, transactions are flat for the year, a trend we expect to continue into 2018. We continue to expect new build to take share relative to the existing home market, as Help to Buy provides a solution for the key break on liquidity in the market, deposits.

BE11:29am

Housing transactions steady in November, Flat YTD. November’s Seasonally Adjusted Housing Transaction numbers saw 104,200 transactions registered in the month. This seasonally adjusted number is 0.6% ahead of October’s adjusted level and 7.1% ahead of the level achieved in 2016, when transactions fell by 8.4% (YoY). Transactions in the past three months are 6.8% ahead of those achieved last year as we continue to see a recovery in the second half of the year. Year to date transactions are 0.4% below 2016 levels. We expect the flat trends to continue into 2018.

Mortgage approvals fall 5% in October. The latest data for Mortgage Approvals saw a 2% fall vs September’s seasonally adjusted number and a 5% decline vs October-16. Despite the October decline, approvals have increased 1.9% in the past 3 months, 2.3% in the past 6 months and are flat YTD. We expect this trend to continue in the final two months of the year, with housing transactions mirroring demand for mortgages.

RICS survey still negative, but an improvement on October. November’s RICS survey remained negative, though slightly better than that seen in October. The national survey showed a negative balance of -5, vs -19 in October, while London saw a value of -18, a significant improvement vs October’s -37. Comments from the survey alluded to increased confidence following the changes to FTB Stamp Duty, while this may have a small impact outside of London, we see little impact in London, particularly for the agents surveyed by RICS, who tend to be centrally based.

Merchanting volumes still strong, +c.9% YTD. Volumes increased 10% in October, in-line with September’s figure. YTD volumes have increased c.9%. Growth has been consistent through the year, apart from March and April where we suspect the timing of Easter (April in 2017, Match in 2016) may have had an impact. Price inflation remains around 1%, having been in this range since early 2013. This compares with price inflation of c.4% in the listed sector, indicating, in our view, that the independent companies are trading for cash over margin.

We acknowledge US tax reform legislation could
drive an acceleration in broader Healthcare M&A but the potential group of buyers for Shire
may be very limited, particularly at this time given ongoing Baxalta integration, Hemlibra haemophilia fears, neuroscience review

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Decision on Neuroscience future soon: We note management is likely nearing a
decision on strategic alternatives for the neuroscience franchise as YE approaches. We
forecast Neuroscience sales to peak around $4bn in 2022E, for an NPV $12bn-$13bn
(c.1100p/share) before allocation of any G&A or pipeline R&D, reflecting an estimated
65%-70% EBITDA contribution margin (25%-30% of Group). We are unsure if significant
value can be created given the franchise's material contribution to the group’s profit, and a
transaction could potentially be negative to the outlook.

Forester @wayne At present the railcos get a great deal - Gold card holders WFH allows them to sell the same seat full-price to someone else!

While it is impossible to say "never" on M&A, Shire does not strike us as an obvious
take-over candidate. Of course, there is presumably a price at which the financial
engineering would work. However, it is not clear to us who would be the natural buyer
for Shire. Shire's specialty focus and mix of therapeutic foci means that most buyers
would struggle to extract substantial operational synergies while escaping from
competition problems, in our view. Shire is based in Ireland, which means a very low
corporate tax rate, which would most probably rise in most scenarios were the
company acquired. It would also be a bold acquisition in our view given the uncertain
trajectory of Shire's haemophilia business.

With capacity to deploy up to $800m on acquisitions (per management), what’s
next? There have been subtle shifts in its acquisition strategy this year. Initially NMC
suggested it would look at opportunities in the EM space within its three healthcare
divisions. In its most recent statement it said it would look to acquire globally for its IVF
business but for its other two verticals (multi-disciplinary and long-term healthcare) it
would predominantly focus on the MENA region. We believe this is a good sign, as it
demonstrates a management team looking at each option on its merits and ensuring it
meets its own strict returns criteria. Many hospital operators have acquired operations
abroad and few have worked out, the South African hospitals being case in point.

A Transforming World: Climate Change Primer

As part of our work on A Transforming World, we update our ongoing work on the Earth-focused theme of climate change solutions with this Primer, setting out the challenges and opportunities offered by the theme, as well as a Primer Picks report.

PM11:53am

#1 global risk: climate change and extreme weather

Extreme weather is recognized as the #1 global risk today, with climate change acting as the ultimate risk multiplier, compounding societal stresses including economic disparity, human migration, and interstate conflict. The 16 warmest years on record have occurred in the 21st century and 2017 is on track to be the 41st consecutive year where global temperatures are above the 20th century average. Extreme weather now covers 10-12% of the globe vs. 0.2% during 1951-1980, with the frequency and severity of heat waves, hurricanes, floods, and droughts intensifying. In a "business as usual" scenario, global temperatures could increase by 4°C (7.2°F) by 2100E, with some regions up to 12°C (21.6°F) hotter. With extreme weather set to impact 60% of the world's population it could cost over 5% of GDP, causing the most damage to emerging markets. In order to maintain the 2°C warming trajectory, seen as the threshold of catastrophic climate change, carbon emissions must peak by 2020, and rapidly fall by c50% by 2050.

Boncoeur @waynej: some political advice, don;t dilute your core message, just give a blanket blurb about ensuring train co performance, blah, blah, balh.
PM11:54am

Cleantech: #1 energy investment opportunity of our time

Disruptive technologies are transforming every sector including climate mitigation, where tech-enabled tools are helping to solve climate challenges in a more effective and ubiquitous manner at an unprecedented pace. Green technology has the potential to deliver 30-40 GtCO2e in emission reductions pa by 2030E, which is more than double the emissions gap for the 2°C trajectory. Renewables and energy efficiency can move us over 80% of the way towards a safer 2°C warming. Clean energy is a US$300bn annual market today, and can provide for 70-80% of cumulative power capacity additions through 2040, by which time 3/4 of generation could come from low-carbon sources. New paradigms are emerging, with some of the fastest growth areas being transport and the adoption of the ACES (autonomous, connected, electric, shared vehicles), and smart cities (integrated approach to renewables, efficiency, electrification, ACES and tech-enabled analytics). Innovative tools such as Green Bonds (5th consecutive year of record issuance) are also becoming a game-changer in linking additional private capital to finance environmental solutions.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

US$70tn+ to 2040E: multiple entry points for investors

We forecast over US$70tn in investments through 2040E for the low-carbon transition. We highlight end-to-end entry points for investors wishing to play the climate change solutions theme, and anticipate fast growth for the likes of renewables, electric vehicles, batteries & storage, LED & lighting, smart grid, YieldCos, and energy efficient- buildings, industrials, IoT, IT, and transport.
